title: Man in 50s drowns spearfishing near Shoalhaven | ABC NEWS
description: A man has died after being pulled from the water at Lobster Bay Beach in Shoalhaven, New South Wales.  The man, believed to be in his 50s, was spearfishing when he became tangled in a float line.  It's the fourth drowning in the state since New Year's Eve. title: World-first organ donation as mum self-administers VAD medication | ABC NEWS
description: An Australian woman is believed to have become the first person in the world to donate organs after self-administering assisted dying medication. It's a landmark precedent that medical experts previously thought was unfeasible. The woman shared her story with the ABC before her death last year. title: WA storm chaser captures red sprite | ABC NEWS
description: A fleeting burst of red light high above a Kimberley storm, in Western Australia's far north, has been caught on camera by a storm-chasing photographer.  The eruption of red, luminous sparks is known by meteorologists and weather enthusiasts as red sprites.  They are the result of a large electrical discharge and flash high above intense active thunderstorms, occurring in the stratosphere and mesosphere.  Photographer Danny Welgama said it was a "see-it-to-believe-it" moment.   Reporting by Ruby Littler.  ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad. It's news when you want it, from Australia's most trusted news organisation. description: At least seven explosions, low-flying aircraft, and one column of smoke have been seen in Venezuela's capital, Caracas, according to eye-witness reports. title: Venezuela declares a state of emergency after explosions around capital | ABC NEWS
description: US officials confirmed to several media outlets that the White House is conducting strikes in Venezuela. The Venezuelan government condemned the attacks, alleging they target civilian and military sites in Caracas. Explosions and low-flying aircraft have been reported, with blasts felt in Miranda, Aragua, and La Guaira. In response, Venezuela has declared a national emergency. title: Venezuelan government demand proof-of-life for Maduro from US | ABC NEWS
description: One journalist in Caracas says it's too early to say how Venezuelans will react to the news that the United States captured the country's president in a nighttime attack. title: Maduro's 'abduction' an 'unprecedented violation of international law' | ABC NEWS
description: International Politics Professor David Dunn says the United States' 'abduction' of Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro is a violation of international law that could set a worrying precedent. He says, while many country's would be privately concerned by Donald Trump's actions, they don't want to risk the ire of the US president so won't publicly condemn the operation.
